item.title: Live Updates: Ukrainians Flee as Russia Bombards Civilians
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky called on Monday for an international tribunal to investigate Russia for war crimes. Delegations from Kyiv and Moscow failed to make progress in Belarus.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Boarding an evacuation train at the central station in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: The One Item They Had to Take When These 6 Afghans Fled
item.description: More than 120,000 people were airlifted out of Afghanistan last August, most with just a few hours to gather their belongings. Here are some of the keepsakes they chose.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Meridith Kohut
item.media:description: Aria Rahmati fled Afghanistan carrying little more than the sapphire and silver ring that had been given to her by a man she cared for.

item.title: Russian Forces Hit Harder in Ukraine After a Fumbled Start
item.description: After days of miscalculation about Ukraine’s resolve to fight, Russian forces are turning toward an old pattern of opening fire on cities and mounting sieges.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with a disabled Russian troop carrier on Friday outside Ukraine’s second-largest city, Kharkiv.

item.title: Russians Face Sanctions and Anxieties of a Costly War
item.description: The ruble plunged, the stock market was shuttered and foreign investors shed holdings in Russian companies, deepening the concern among citizens who had become accustomed to the perks of globalization.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a supermarket in Moscow.

item.title: In Germany, Threats Grow as Far Right and Pandemic Protestors Merge
item.description: In the former Communist East, security officials worry that a long-running movement against Covid restrictions is becoming an incubator of political violence.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times

item.title: Singapore’s Latest Ruling on Gay Sex Is ‘Cold Comfort,’ Activists Say
item.description: Plaintiffs had hoped the Court of Appeal would overturn the colonial-era law. Instead, the top court said it was not “an architect of social policy” and that any change was up to Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Feline Lim/Reuters
item.media:description: Participants at Pink Dot, an annual event organized in support of the L.G.B.T.Q. community in Singapore, calling in 2019 for the repeal of Section 377A.

item.title: Pakistan Will Cut Energy Prices to Offset Rising Costs After Invasion
item.description: Critics said the move by Prime Minister Imran Khan was aimed at stemming increasing criticism of his handling of the economy and would provide only temporary relief.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Rizwan Tabassum/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pakistanis at a market in Karachi watched Prime Minister Imran Khan address the nation on Monday.

item.title: Why the Chinese Internet Is Cheering Russia’s Invasion
item.description: As the world overwhelmingly condemns the assault on Ukraine, online opinion in China is mostly pro-Russia, pro-war and pro-Putin.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bombed Ukrainian home in south Kyiv. Many Chinese social media users have praised President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and accepted his justification for invading Ukraine.

item.title: Climate Change's Effects Outpacing Ability to Adapt, I.P.C.C. Warns
item.description: Countries aren’t doing nearly enough to protect against the disasters to come as the planet keeps heating up, a major new scientific report concludes.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A seawall construction in low-lying metropolitan Manila, Philippines. Many developing countries lack the resources to prepare for the more serious climate-related threats still to come.

item.title: Floods Engulf Brisbane and Kill 9 in Northeastern Australia
item.description: Days of downpours have pummeled Queensland and New South Wales, with the authorities describing the wild weather as “waves of water just coming down.”
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Jason O'Brien/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Using small boats to travel through floodwaters in Lismore, Australia, on Monday.

item.title: North Korea Launches a Ballistic Missile, South Korea Says
item.description: Flight data suggested that the missile launched Sunday was less powerful than the last one the North tested, four weeks ago.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Ahn Young-Joon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Watching news coverage of a North Korean missile launch in Seoul last month.

item.title: Russia's War With Ukraine Is Already Costing Russian Economy
item.description: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking past Red Square in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: Putin’s Aggression Leaves His Right-Wing Fan Club Squirming
item.description: The Russian strongman has for years been idolized by a Who’s Who of populist, nationalist leaders. They are now stumbling over what to say.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Mikhail Klimentyev/Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Rally party, met President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2017.

item.title: Ties That Bind Putin and Xi Tested by Russia's Ukraine Invasion
item.description: The two autocrats have brought their countries closer together than ever. But for China, the costs of Russia’s adventurism could be high.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Druzhinin
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow in 2019. Mr. Xi called Mr. Putin his “best friend” during that visit.

item.title: Satellite Internet Terminals, Sent by Elon Musk, Arrive in Ukraine
item.description: Responding to a plea by a Ukrainian official, Mr. Musk delivered an unknown number of his Starlink terminals, which offer online connection via orbiting satellites, bypassing conventional providers.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Craig Bailey/Florida Today, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off at Kennedy Space Center, Fla., in February, carrying a batch of Starlink satellites.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A bloody attack on Ukraine’s second-largest city.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Bobok/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A destroyed school in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Tech Companies Help Defend Ukraine Against Cyberattacks
item.description: After years of talks about the need for public-private partnerships to combat cyberattacks, the war in Ukraine is stress-testing the system.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians gather in a train station in Kyiv in an effort to leave the city shortly after the Russian invasion began.

item.title: Chinese Company Removed as Operator of Cobalt Mine in Congo
item.description: A court has given the Congolese control of one of the world’s largest sources of cobalt while allegations against the mine’s Chinese owners are investigated.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Jonny Hogg/Reuters
item.media:description: The court ruling stems from a dispute over billions of dollars the Congolese government says it is owed by the Chinese owner of the Tenke Fungurume mine.

item.title: U.S. Expels 12 Russian Diplomats for Spying
item.description: The move is part of a larger effort to isolate Russia diplomatically and economically since it invaded Ukraine last week.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Justin Lane/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Rallies in support of Ukraine outside the United Nations headquarters in New York on Monday.

item.title: A Few Members of Russia's Parliament Speak Out Against War
item.description: In a rare show of dissent, three deputies of the State Duma have expressed regret about the attack.
item.dc:creator: Ada Petriczko
item.media:credit: Sergei Ilnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: People walking in front of the Russian Duma building in Moscow, on February 22.

item.title: Russian Rocket Kills Civilians as First Talks Show No Progress
item.description: The deadly rocket assault on a residential area of Ukraine’s second-largest city signaled an escalation of Russian tactics, and overshadowed efforts at diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Steven Erlanger and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Sergey Bobok/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A destroyed school on Monday in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: What Questions Do You Have About Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine?
item.description: New York Times reporters will answer reader questions about the war, the world’s response and the effects of sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: People took cover in a sports center that became an improvised bomb shelter late Sunday evening, in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: In Miami, a Ukrainian Art Show Becomes Unintentionally Timely
item.description: A Kyiv couple stage a socially charged exhibition in South Florida as their Voloshyn Gallery back home becomes a bomb shelter.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Alfonso Duran for The New York Times
item.media:description: An installation view of Julia and Max Voloshyn’s pop-up exhibition of Ukrainian artworks in a Miami warehouse.

item.title: Biden Administration Faces Pressure to Let Ukrainians Stay in U.S.
item.description: Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, has called on the administration to offer Temporary Protected Status to Ukrainians who are on short-term visas or have no documentation.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the White House to protest against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Ukraine War Tests the Power of Tech Giants
item.description: Google, Meta, Twitter, Telegram and others are levers in the conflict, caught between demands from Ukraine, Russia, the European Union and the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse—Getty Images
item.media:description: A cellphone user in Moscow. The war in Ukraine has become a defining geopolitical moment for the world’s biggest tech companies.

item.title: Planned Europe-Russia Joint Mars Mission Called “Very Unlikely”
item.description: The ExoMars mission, postponed in 2020 because of the pandemic and technical issues, may miss its window to launch this year because of sanctions imposed against Russia over the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Joey Roulette
item.media:credit: Ben Stansall/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A working prototype of the Rosalind Franklin ExoMars rover at the Airbus Defence and Space facility in Stevenage, north of London, in 2019.

item.title: Invasion Brings Russia Global Repudiation With Cold War Echoes
item.description: From culture to commerce, sports to travel, the world is shunning Russia in myriad ways to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aeroflot airplanes at the Sheremetyevo Airport in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: Fighting Rages On in Ukraine
item.description: Sanctions hit Russia, crushing the ruble.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Sergey Bobok/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A school destroyed in Ukraine near its border with Russia.

item.title: Treasured Paintings Burned in Russian Invasion, Ukrainian Officials Say
item.description: Roughly 25 works by the painter Maria Primachenko were destroyed at a museum in Ivankiv, Ukraine’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Graham Bowley

item.title: Russian Artists Speak Out Against War, but Fear Reprisals
item.description: Two Russian artists have pulled out of the Venice Biennale and thousands are signing antiwar petitions.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Initial Talks Between Russia and Ukraine Yield No Resolution
item.description: Russia’s delegation leader said the next meeting would take place once more along the Ukraine-Belarus border in the “coming days.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: BelTA
item.media:description: In this photograph provided by Belarussian state media, the Russian delegation, on the left, and the Ukrainian delegation, on the right, during negotiations in the Gomel region Monday in Belarus.

item.title: Wales and Scotland Move to Relax Some Covid Restrictions
item.description: Various masking and vaccination rules will ease, though the approach is more gradual than England’s.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The regional government in Wales said it was dropping mask requirements for cinemas and some other indoor public venues. Masked moviegoers were spaced far apart in May at a theater in Cardiff, Wales.

item.title: Pfizer Shot Is Far Less Effective in 5- to 11-Year-Olds Than in Older Kids, New Data Show
item.description: While protection against hospitalization is still strong, the vaccine offered almost no protection against infection, even just a month after full vaccination.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Joseph Prezioso/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A 10-year-old receiving the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at Hartford Hospital in Hartford, Conn.

item.title: Switzerland Says it Will Freeze Russian Assets
item.description: The decision came amid mounting public anger at Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Fabrice Coffrini
item.media:description: President Ignazio Cassis of Switzerland addressing a session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, in Geneva, on Monday.

item.title: Zelensky Urges the E.U. to Admit Ukraine Immediately
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Associated Press

item.title: US Escalates Sanctions With a Freeze on Russian Central Bank Assets
item.description: The action is likely to fuel rapid inflation in Russia as it wages war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers in Moscow on Saturday. Senior Biden administration officials predicted inflation in Russia would soon spike and economic activity would contract as the country’s currency lost value.

item.title: Classroom Disruptions
item.description: We look at the surprising number of recent classroom shutdowns in the U.S. And the latest from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tomas Ovalle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Noelle Rodriguez moved her hair salon to her home in Fresno, Calif.

item.title: Russia's Stock Market Closes and Ruble Crashes as Sanctions Hit
item.description: The hectic moves were the first signs that Western sanctions were shaking the foundations of Russia’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People outside a currency exchange shop in Moscow on Saturday.

item.title: In Search of Panama’s Elusive Spider Monkeys
item.description: Environmental initiatives in the Azuero Peninsula offer hope for the future of a critically endangered subspecies.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stirn

item.title: Here’s the latest news from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s nuclear forces on alert.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian flag being raised over a newly-established checkpoint on Sunday in Hushchyntsi, Ukraine.

item.title: Why Kyrie Irving Still Won’t Play in Brooklyn if Some Covid Restrictions End Next Week
item.description: Barclays Center would remain under a private-sector vaccine mandate that took effect in December.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Benny Sieu/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Kyrie Irving, left, in a game in Milwaukee on Saturday. He has played in only 15 of the Nets’ 61 games, in part because of his refusal to be vaccinated.

item.title: Capitol's Mask Mandate Being Lifted in Time for State of the Union
item.description: This year’s address from the president, unlike last year’s, is open to all members of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mask mandate on the House floor at the U.S. Capitol is being lifted.

item.title: Putin Declares a Nuclear Alert, and Biden Seeks De-escalation
item.description: When the Russian leader ordered his nuclear forces into “special combat readiness,” the U.S. could have gone on high alert. Instead, the administration tried not to inflame him.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Svetlana Akimova, 82, sheltered in a parking garage in Kyiv on Saturday as heavy fighting took place outside her apartment building.

item.title: In Foreign Policy U-Turn, Germany Ups Military Spending and Arms Ukraine
item.description: Germany agrees to strengthen its military in the latest foreign policy about-face amid pressure from allies and horror at Russia’s attack on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Gregor Fischer/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The German army’s barracks in Munster earlier this month.

item.title: Pyeongchang Still Awaits Its Olympic Payoff
item.description: One of South Korea’s poorest regions hoped that hosting the 2018 Games would bring tourists and prosperity. It hasn’t really happened.
item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho
item.media:credit: Tim Franco for The New York Times
item.media:description: A reminder of the 2018 Winter Olympics in Gangneung, South Korea, which hosted some of the events.

item.title: Ukraine Agrees to Talks With Russia, but Fighting Still Rages
item.description: Putin, accusing the West of “aggressive statements,” puts nuclear forces on alert. Kyiv remains in Russian cross-hairs as Ukrainians push back.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Steven Erlanger

item.title: War in Ukraine Forces Israel Into a Delicate Balancing Act
item.description: Israel is a strong ally of the United States, and its leaders have a good relationship with Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s Jewish president. But Israel also doesn’t want to provoke Russia.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Isabel Kershner and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Oded Balilty/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pro-Ukraine demonstrators outside the Russian Embassy in Tel Aviv on Thursday, after Russian troops attacked Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainian Citizens Prepare to Fight Russian Army
item.description: In cities and towns in Central Ukraine that have not yet heard the boom of Russian artillery fire, residents spent the weekend preparing furiously for the possibly of an attack.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilian volunteers in Dnipro organize and pack donations for distribution, and load empty bottles to be used for Molotov cocktails from a collection point on Sunday.

item.title: Ukrainians in Britain Take Up the Cause Back Home
item.description: Whether vowing to kill Russians or offering medical supplies, Ukrainian citizens are too impatient to sit idly by.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Bilyy, a deliveryman living in Britain, drove for two days hoping to join the fight for Ukraine. “Nothing will change if I stay in my house,” he said.

item.title: Ukraine War Forces Hungary’s Orban Into Political Contortions
item.description: The pro-Russia, anti-immigrant Hungarian prime minister, who denounced any sanctions against Russia just weeks ago, has been forced to reverse himself as an election looms.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Novak
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Several hundred people who fled Ukraine huddled in small groups on Sunday at the train station in Zahony, Hungary, trying to figure out their next move.

item.title: Norway’s sovereign wealth fund plans to divest from the Russian market.
item.dc:creator: Erin Woo

item.title: EU Will Ask States to Grant Asylum to Ukrainian Refugees for Up to 3 Years
item.description: More than 300,000 people have fled into the European Union since Russia invaded Ukraine on Thursday, the bloc said, and it is expecting millions more.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: People crossing from Ukraine into Hungary at the border in Zahony on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Ukraine Agrees to Talks
item.description: Plus new research into the pandemic’s origins and North Korea’s latest missile test.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katya, 25, sits with her mother, Oleksandre, 50, in a shelter in a gymnasium in Kyiv, Ukraine, February 26, 2022.

item.title: New York Ends Its Mask Mandate for Schools
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the statewide mask mandate in schools would end on Wednesday, and Mayor Eric Adams planned to lift pandemic measures in the city on March 7.
item.dc:creator: Grace Ashford, Eliza Shapiro and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.media:description: An elementary school in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, last month. Mayor Eric Adams said on Sunday that school mask mandates will likely end on March 7 in New York City.

item.title: Once Sleepy and Picturesque, Ukrainian Villages Mobilize for War
item.description: While Russian assaults on Ukrainian cities have drawn most of the attention in the war’s early days, civilians in country towns have joined the fight, putting aside the routines of daily village life.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian flag being raised over a newly-established checkpoint on Sunday in Hushchyntsi, Ukraine.

item.title: How Zelensky Rallied Ukrainians, and the World, Against Putin
item.description: Mr. Zelensky’s decision to remain in the capital, Kyiv, while it’s under Russian attack has moved many.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Volodymyr Zelensky, via Facebook
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky has made effective use of social media throughout his candidacy and presidency.

item.title: Europe escalates measures against Russia with flight bans and weapons for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Maxim Shemetov/Reuters
item.media:description: Sheremetyevo International Airport in Moscow in 2020.

item.title: Memo from antsy executives: Plans to return to in-person work are real this time.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: TIAA Financial Services in Manhattan is targeting March 7 for employees to return to the office.
